reviews.review_msg: OK prof, but avoid his TA Paula, she is a very strict marker. Horribly high expectations on students during tutorial,need to facilitate your own tutorial, but she herself made boring presentation
This course is very informative but it started at 9:30am which makes the attendance rate low...interesting course but hard

I took a few classes with Shane and he is easily the best CMNS prof at SFU. He is a really nice person, always makes time for students and is fair to the point of being a pushover. Very passionate about what he is teaching and it shows. Interesting lectures and readings; I was always happy to attend lectures with Shane.
I loved this environmental course. At times he was a bit unclear about assignments but he was very passionate about the material he was teaching. Shane is a great prof.

The lecture could be more interesting if he doesn't copy it right off the text. More depth should be covered in each topic instead of just regurgitating the text. He needs to understand that not every student have a strong environmental background

Professional, conscientious, put a lot of thought into his course. Too much material is fired at you - it'd be better if there was less material but more depth. e.g., terms such as "experiential commensurability" that are explained in about 4 seconds - in one ear & out the other! Needs to slow down & engage more with the class.  & smile.

Not helpful at all, the Prof and TA will ask you to go read your text book. Really no point going to lecture, if we are suppose to learn everything from textbook. The quiz and midterm was hilarious, it ask about things that wasn't taught in class, or something that has no right answer, but you will lose marks for not giving enough points.

agree Anderson is a nice person, but expects too much for a new class CMNS388. His requirement for the projects are messy and unclear. Waste of time going to this lectures, because he talk super slow, and can't hear him speak sometimes. Ending up with wasting the whole lecture on just one topic.
